clean_text: Earth Lusca, a fictional advanced persistent threat (APT) group, initiated Operation Wocao by conducting vulnerability scanning on public-facing servers to identify weaknesses, while simultaneously establishing fake LinkedIn profiles to enhance credibility for social engineering. The actors then employed spearphishing attachments to drop malicious.ps1 into the Temp directory, which used PowerShell to gather credential data from Windows Credential Manager and inhibit system recovery by deleting backup files via vssadmin. Concurrently, they compromised the supply chain by modifying legitimate development_tools.exe to include a backdoor before distribution, and utilized SEO poisoning by embedding hidden div elements with popular product names into a compromised website to lure victims. For infrastructure, Earth Lusca purchased servers with Bitcoin to host command-and-control (C2) operations, where they leveraged valid accounts to maintain persistent access to victim networks and executed arbitrary commands on compromised ESXi guest VMs using the vSphere Web Services SDK. In containerized environments, the attacker updated ClusterRoleBinding.yaml to grant cluster-wide permissions to a rogue service account, while loading a kernel extension via kextload to re-establish connections after reboot. Communication was facilitated through non-application layer protocols such as TCP and UDP for stealthy data exfiltration.

llm_raw_response.title: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory: Fictional APT Campaign 'Operation Wocao' Targeting Critical Infrastructure
llm_raw_response.summary: This advisory details a simulated campaign by a fictional threat actor, Earth Lusca, targeting critical infrastructure sectors through a multi-vector approach involving reconnaissance, phishing, supply chain compromise, and persistence mechanisms. The campaign leverages valid accounts and cloud infrastructure to maintain access and execute malicious activities across Windows, ESXi, and Kubernetes environments.
llm_raw_response.full_report_text: Earth Lusca, a fictional advanced persistent threat (APT) group, initiated Operation Wocao by conducting vulnerability scanning [T1595.002] on public-facing servers to identify weaknesses, while simultaneously establishing fake LinkedIn profiles [T1585] to enhance credibility for social engineering. The actors then employed spearphishing attachments [T1598.002] to drop malicious.ps1 into the Temp directory, which used PowerShell to gather credential data from Windows Credential Manager [T1555.004] and inhibit system recovery [T1490] by deleting backup files via vssadmin. Concurrently, they compromised the supply chain [T1195] by modifying legitimate development_tools.exe to include a backdoor before distribution, and utilized SEO poisoning [T1608.006] by embedding hidden div elements with popular product names into a compromised website to lure victims. For infrastructure, Earth Lusca purchased servers with Bitcoin [T1583.004] to host command-and-control (C2) operations, where they leveraged valid accounts [T1078] to maintain persistent access to victim networks and executed arbitrary commands on compromised ESXi guest VMs using the vSphere Web Services SDK [T1675]. In containerized environments, the attacker updated ClusterRoleBinding.yaml to grant cluster-wide permissions [T1098.006] to a rogue service account, while loading a kernel extension via kextload [T1547.006] to re-establish connections after reboot. Communication was facilitated through non-application layer protocols [T1095] such as TCP and UDP for stealthy data exfiltration.
